title: England dismiss feisty Argentina after Tomás Lavanini sees red
text:
England are safely into the knockout stages of the Rugby World Cup with a game to spare after a six-try victory over a 14-man Argentina. The Pumas had the lock Tomás Lavanini sent off in the first quarter for a high tackle on Owen Farrell and their opponents took full advantage to book a guaranteed spot in the last eight.

They will now meet France in Yokohama on Saturday with the winners set to finish top of Pool C and, potentially, face Australia in the quarter-finals. England, in the meantime, will be sweating on the fitness of the No 8 Billy Vunipola, who hurt an ankle in the first half and did not reappear after half-time.

By then, however, the contest was in effect over, Lavanini having been sent off in the 18th minute for a tackle that made contact with the head of a stooping Farrell. Had the fly-half been standing upright it would probably have been a legal hit but players are now expected to allow some margin for error and, even at 6ft 7in tall, Lavanini should have aimed lower in the first instance.

It left the previously bubbling atmosphere around the ground suddenly as flat as a pancake, with the raucous Argentina fans not alone in feeling instantly deflated. Leicester may benefit if Lavanini arrives slightly earlier than planned in the east Midlands but, equally, Premiership referees will now be waiting for him.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Nigel Owens sends off Tomás Lavanini (centre) with Argentina trailing only 5-3. Photograph: David Rogers/Getty Images

Though it took a while for England to exploit their numerical advantage, Argentina were forced to make twice as many tackles as their opponents in the first 40 minutes alone and Eddie Jones’s side were already three tries up by half-time through Jonny May, Elliot Daly and Ben Youngs.

May’s early score was nicely served up for him by a scampering George Ford while Daly, after an initial juggle, showed good pace to get around his opposite number, Emiliano Boffelli. Youngs’s effort was scored from closer range but was a nice way to mark his 92nd cap, putting him third on England’s all-time Test appearance list.

Vunipola will have rather less fond memories of the evening. His departure left his side with three specialist flankers in the back row but, on this occasion, it mattered not. Ford, alert as ever, dived over for the bonus point score five minutes after the restart and Farrell, having rediscovered his kicking boots, added the conversion and a subsequent penalty.

Further late tries for the Exeter pair of Jack Nowell and Luke Cowan-Dickie completed a forgettable night for a frustrated Argentina, who last failed to qualify for the knockout stages at a Rugby World Cup back in 2003. Their only modest consolations was a second-half try for the winger Matías Moroni and an 88th cap off the bench for their captain, Agustín Creevy, making him the most capped player in his country’s history.
description: England are into the knockout stages of the Rugby World Cup with a game to spare after a 39-10 victory over an Argentina side who had Tomás Lavanini sent off when trailing only 5-3
